title: Saving 50p a day could have turned you into a millionaire - here's how
text:

The 50p piece entered circulation exactly 50 years ago - on 14 October 1969.

At the time a single one of the new coins could have bought five pints of beer in a pub, but if you'd put that money away instead of spending it, you could be sitting on far more now.

But only if you chose to put it in the right place at the time.

“If you’d chosen not to spend your shiny new 50p, and put it into an easy access savings account instead, you’d be kicking yourself now," Hargreaves Lansdown personal finance analyst Sarah Coles explained.

(Image: Mirrorpix)

That's because, over the half-century since it launched, that 50p would have grown to just £6.48.

By contrast, price rises mean you'd need to spend an average of £8.29 today to buy as much now as it could have bought you then.

But, if rather than dropping it into a savings account, you'd put it in the markets, you'd be sitting pretty.

"If you’d put it into the Scottish Mortgage Investment Trust you’d have £255, and if you’d picked what went on to be the best-performing share in the market, you’d have an impressive £1,857," Coles said.

(Image: PA)

And if you'd taken that first 50p, and then added to it with another 50p each day since, you'd be a multi-millionaire.

Hargreaves Lansdown figures show that putting that cash in the Scottish Mortgage Investment Trust would see you with £2.8million now, while putting it into the most successful single stock of the period would mean you have £12 million.

Even with its reduced spending power now, starting to put just 50p a day into the markets can bring good results if you keep going.

"Of course, 50p a day won’t have quite the same impact today, but it could still build you a nest egg – and in 50 years could leave you around £22,000 better off,” Coles said.
description: Fifty years ago the world's first seven-sided coin was released as the 50p entered circulation - and if you'd used it right since then you'd now be sitting on millions
